roundup: ['Fall in number of positive cases reporting loss of taste or smell', 'The percentage of people testing positive who reported loss of taste or smell continued to decrease between December 2021 and January 2022.', 'People previously infected with coronavirus (COVID-19) continued to be less likely to test positive than those who have not experienced a prior infection, according to data collected in the fortnight up to 12 February 2022.', 'Those who reported working in the education sector continued to be more likely to test positive in comparison with other working adults. This is likely because of the recent high rate of infe ctions among school children.', 'People who had travelled abroad in the last 28 days also continued to be more likely to test positive than those who had not. People who live in multiple occupancy households continued to be more likely to test positive than people living alone.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read more about the characteristics of people testing positive for COVID-19', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/coronaviruscovid19infectionsurveyukcharacteristicsofpeopletestingpositiveforcovid192march2022'}]

roundup: ['7 in 10 positive cases would isolate even if not legally required', 'Around 7 in 10 (72%) people who tested positive for coronavirus (COVID-19) in England in early February said they would continue to self-isolate even if it was not legally required.', 'Almost two-thirds (63%) of those who tested positive would take a COVID-19 test if they had to buy one. This was similar for those from the most deprived and the least deprived areas (59% and 64% respectively).', 'The latest responses to the COVID Test and Trace Cases Insights Survey were collected between 7 and 12 February 2022, before the legal requirement to self-isolate was removed in England.', 'The majority (80%) of respondents who tested positive for COVID-19 in early February fully complied with self-isolation rules. This was in line with rate reported in the previous month.', 'More than 9 in 10 (92%) said they had no difficulties in accessing COVID-19 tests, a significant improvement compared with January (74%).']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest bulletin on coronavirus and self-isolation after testing positive in England', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/healthandwellbeing/bulletins/coronavirusandselfisolationaftertestingpositiveinengland/latest'}]

roundup: ['Deaths involving COVID-19 continue to fall', 'The number of deaths in the UK involving coronavirus (COVID-19) fell to 969 in the week ending 18 February 2022. This was 217 fewer than the previous week, accounting for around 1 in every 13 deaths (7.6%).', 'There were 12,742 total deaths registered in the UK in the week ending 18 February 2022, which was 6.4% below the five-year average.', 'The number of deaths involving COVID-19 decreased in England compared with the previous week and increased slightly in Wales.', 'Of the 863 deaths registered in England and Wales where “novel coronavirus (COVID-19)” was mentioned on the death certificate, 64.8% (559 deaths) had this recorded as the underlying cause of death.', 'Between 13 March 2020 and 18 February 2022, there have been 121,371 excess deaths above the five-year average in England and Wales; of these, 116,604 were recorded in England and 6,090 were recorded in Wales.', 'Our data are based on deaths registered in England and Wales and include all deaths where “novel coronavirus (COVID-19)” was mentioned on the death certificate. Weekly figures are available by local authority and health board.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest bulletin on deaths registered in England and Wales', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/birthsdeathsandmarriages/deaths/bulletins/deathsregisteredweeklyinenglandandwalesprovisional/latest'}]

roundup: ['16.7% of care resident deaths have involved COVID-19 since March 2020', 'Since the start of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, of the 274,063 deaths to care home residents in England and Wales, 45,632 (16.7%) involved COVID-19.', 'There were more total deaths of care home residents compared to the five-year average in the first wave of the pandemic with 26,035 excess deaths in England and 1,046 excess deaths in Wales. In the second and third waves, however, total deaths fell below the five-year average.', 'In England, total deaths of care home residents increased by 16.5% between the first and second waves with 85,305 and 99,380 deaths respectively. Following this, deaths decreased by 23.9% between the second and third waves (75,664) deaths. The proportion of deaths involving COVID-19 was highest in the first wave (23.2%) and lowest in the third wave (3.6%).', 'In Wales, total deaths of care home residents in Wales increased by 30.0% between the first and second waves with 4,196 and 5,454 deaths respectively. It decreased by 27.0% between the second and third waves (3,980 deaths). The proportion of deaths involving COVID-19 was highest in the second wave (23.8%) and lowest in the third wave (4.9%).']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest bulletin on deaths involving COVID-19 in the care sector', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/deathsinvolvingcovid19inthecaresectorenglandandwalesdeathsregisteredbetweenweekending9april2021andweekending11february2022'}]

roundup: ['Long COVID and mental disorders in school students', 'Of primary school pupils with long COVID, 30.0% had a probable mental disorder, a significantly higher proportion than the 7.7% of those without long COVID. Among secondary school pupils, 22.6% of those who had experienced long COVID had a probable mental disorder, compared with 13.6% of those who hadn’t experienced long COVID.', 'Since March 2020, 1.0% of primary school-aged pupils and 2.7% of secondary school-aged pupils experienced long COVID.', 'Among students who had previously received a positive coronavirus (COVID-19) test, 5.2% experienced an ongoing symptom of loss of taste or smell, compared with 0.4% of those who hadn’t tested positive. This is the only symptom that was significantly more prevalent among students with a previous coronavirus infection.', 'It is estimated that 82% of secondary school pupils and 40% of primary school pupils tested positive for coronavirus antibodies between November and December 2021. About a third of pupils aged four to seven years (33.9%) tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 antibodies.', 'Secondary school pupils over the age of 12 years were eligible to have a vaccine at the time of testing so may have had antibodies from either natural infection or vaccination.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the bulletin on mental health and long COVID from the COVID-19 Schools Infection Survey', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/covid19schoolsinfectionsurveyenglandmentalhealthandlongcovidnovembertodecember2021'}]

roundup: ['Infections continue to fall in England and Northern Ireland', 'The percentage of people estimated to test positive for coronavirus (COVID-19) fell in England and Northern Ireland in the week ending 26 February 2022.', 'Trends were uncertain in Wales in the latest week after two consecutive weeks of decreases.', 'In Scotland, the percentage of people testing positive for COVID-19 rose in the latest week to around 1 in 19 (5.79%) of people.', 'In the same period, the percentage of people testing positive for COVID-19 decreased for all age groups except those aged 70 and over.', 'The percentage of people testing positive continues to fluctuate for those aged 70 and over, with an increase in the most recent week.', 'The estimated number of people living in private households (not in hospitals, care homes and/or other communal establishments) that had COVID-19 in the most recent week was:', ' - 1,933,500 people (1 in 30) in England', ' - 94,200 people (1 in 30) in Wales', ' - 106,300 people (1 in 17) in Northern Ireland', ' - 280,500 people (1 in 19) in Scotland']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest Coronavirus (COVID-19) Infection Survey bulletin', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/bulletins/coronaviruscovid19infectionsurveypilot/latest'}]

roundup: ['Concern about coronavirus pandemic at its lowest', 'Just over 4 in 10 adults (41%) reported they were very or somewhat worried about the effect of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic on their lives right now. This is the lowest we have seen this figure since the start of the pandemic.', 'Around one-third (32%) of adults reported always or often maintaining social distancing. This is the lowest proportion since data collection on this measure started in September 2020.', 'The share of working adults that only work from home is now at 15%, down from 26% over the period 6 to 16 January 2022. During the same period, the percentage that only travelled to work increased from 49% to 56%, while 13% report both working from home and travelling to work.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest bulletin on the social impacts of COVID-19', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/coronavirusandthesocialimpactsongreatbritain4march2022'}]

roundup: ['Almost half those with long COVID have had it for at least a year', 'An estimated 1.5 million people (or 2.4%) living in private households said they were living with long COVID, as of the end of January 2022.', 'Of those who said they had long COVID, 685,000 people (or 45%) were experiencing symptoms at least a year after the initial infection.', 'The estimates in this analysis refer to self-reported long COVID – symptoms persisting for more than four weeks after the first suspected coronavirus (COVID-19) infection that were not explained by something else.', 'Almost two-thirds (65%) of those with self-reported long COVID said that it affected their day-to-day activities, equivalent to 989,000 people. Of those, 281,000 said that they were “limited a lot”.', 'Fatigue continued to be the most reported symptom, affecting 51% of those with self-reported long COVID.', 'As a proportion of the UK population, prevalence of self-reported long COVID was greatest in people aged 35 to 49 years, females, people living in more deprived areas, those working in teaching and education, social care or healthcare, and those with another activity-limiting health condition or disability.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest insights on COVID-19 and infections', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/articles/coronaviruscovid19latestinsights/infections'}, {'text': 'Read the latest bulletin on prevalence of ongoing symptoms following coronavirus (COVID-19) infection in the UK', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/bulletins/prevalenceofongoingsymptomsfollowingcoronaviruscovid19infectionintheuk/latest'}]

roundup: ['Avoidable mortality rates at highest level since 2010', 'In 2020, 22.8% of all deaths in Great Britain (GB) were considered avoidable. This figure represents about 153,000 of the total 672,000 deaths.', 'The avoidable mortality rate for GB was significantly higher than all years since 2010.', 'Avoidable mortality looks at deaths from causes considered avoidable, treatable, or preventable, given timely and effective healthcare or public health interventions.', 'Wales had the highest avoidable mortality rate for deaths due to coronavirus (COVID-19) with 36.1 deaths per 100,000 people. Scotland had the lowest rate with 28.5 deaths per 100,000 people. England had 34.9 deaths due to COVID-19 per 100,000 people.', 'From 2018 to 2020, Blackpool local authority had the highest male preventable mortality rate with 355.8 deaths per 100,000 males. Middlesbrough had the highest female rate with 205.4 deaths per 100,000 females.']

['9 in 10 travellers arriving to the UK are double vaccinated', 'Most UK and overseas residents arriving in the UK in January 2022 have received at least two coronavirus (COVID-19) vaccinations, at 98% and 96%, respectively.', 'According to the International Passenger Survey (IPS), the proportion of UK residents arriving in the UK who have received more than two COVID-19 vaccinations doubled between December and January, increasing from 28% to 56%.', 'Of travellers arriving in the UK, most continue to think that having a COVID-19 test prior to arrival is either “very important” or “quite important” for safety; 81% of UK residents and 87% of overseas residents in January 2022 agreed with these statements.', 'The increase in the percentage of UK residents who had received more than two vaccinations reflects the expansion of the National Health Service (NHS) booster programme to all adults over 18 years of age, with those eligible to have been offered a vaccination by the end of January 2022.', ' - Attitudes towards COVID-19 among passengers travelling into the UK: August 2021 to January 2022']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Manual', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/attitudestowardscovid19amongpassengerstravellingintoandoutoftheukaugust2021tojanuary2022'}]

roundup: ['COVID-19 antibodies remain high', 'The percentage of the UK population estimated to have antibodies protecting them against COVID-19 remains high on all measures.', 'More than 98% of adults in each constituent country of the UK were estimated to have COVID-19 antibodies in the week beginning 14 February 2022.', ' - In England 98.4% (95% credible interval 98.1% to 98.6%)', ' - In Wales 98.3% (97.9% to 98.7%)', ' - In Northern Ireland 98.1% (97.1% to 98.7%)', ' - In Scotland 98.3% (97.8% to 98.6%)', 'While levels of antibodies are highest among older age groups, they remain high in children aged eight years and above.', 'The percentage of children estimated to have antibodies range from 93.9% to 94.7% among those aged 12 to 15 years and 71.3% to 78.8% among those aged 8 to 11 years.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest COVID-19 Infection Survey, UK: antibody and vaccination data', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/coronaviruscovid19infectionsurveyukantibodyandvaccinationdata9march2022'}]

roundup: ['Deaths involving COVID-19 continue to fall', 'The number of deaths in the UK involving coronavirus (COVID-19) fell to 878 in the week ending 25 February 2022. This was 92 fewer than the previous week, accounting for around 1 in every 14 deaths (6.9%).', 'There were 12,648 total deaths registered in the UK in the week ending 25 February 2022, which was 5.5% below the five-year average.', 'Of the 766 deaths registered in England and Wales where “novel coronavirus (COVID-19)” was mentioned on the death certificate, 65.7% (503 deaths) had this recorded as the underlying cause of death.', 'Between 13 March 2020 and 25 February 2022, there have been 120,731 excess deaths above the five-year average in England and Wales; of these, 116,021 were recorded in England and 6,038 were\u202frecorded in Wales.', 'Our\u202fdata\u202fare based on deaths registered in England and Wales and include all deaths where “novel coronavirus (COVID-19)” was mentioned on the death certificate. Weekly figures are available by\u202flocal authority and health board.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest bulletin on deaths registered in England and Wales', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/birthsdeathsandmarriages/deaths/bulletins/deathsregisteredweeklyinenglandandwalesprovisional/latest'}]

roundup: ['Infections have risen across the UK', 'The percentage of people estimated to test positive for coronavirus (COVID-19) rose in England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland in the week ending 5 March 2022 (6 March 2022 for Scotland).', 'The estimated number of people living in private households (not in hospitals, care homes or other communal establishments) who had COVID-19 in the most recent week was:', ' - 2,073,900 people (1 in 25) in England', ' - 97,900 people (1 in 30) in Wales', ' - 143,800 people (1 in 13) in Northern Ireland', ' - 299,900 people (1 in 18) in Scotland', 'The percentage of infections compatible with the Omicron BA.2 variant increased in England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland. The percentage of infections compatible with the Omicron BA.1 variant decreased in England, Wales and Scotland, while the trend was uncertain in Northern Ireland.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest Coronavirus (COVID-19) Infection Survey bulletin', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/bulletins/coronaviruscovid19infectionsurveypilot/latest'}]

roundup: ['Most vaccinated coronavirus (COVID-19) contacts take daily tests', 'The majority (67%) of vaccinated close contacts of a coronavirus (COVID-19) case reported undertaking daily testing and completing all required daily lateral flow tests (LFTs) between 21 and 26 February 2022. Legal restrictions for contacts of a positive COVID-19 case were lifted on 24 February 2022.', 'The proportion of people who often or always reported their LFT results increased from 34% of people aged 18 to 29 years to 59% of those aged 70 years and over.', 'Among the 24% of people who did not take daily LFTs following close contact, the most common reasons given were respondents not thinking taking tests were useful (33%) and not having access to enough tests (15%).', 'Around one-fifth of respondents (18%) felt the current isolation guidance for those who are double vaccinated was insufficient to keep the public safe. Around three-fifths (61%) reported taking additional measures to keep themselves and others safe, beyond government guidelines.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read Coronavirus and behaviour of the vaccinated population after being in contact with a positive case in England: 21 February to 26 February 2022', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/coronavirusandbehaviourofthevaccinatedpopulationafterbeingincontactwithapositivecaseinengland21februaryto26february2022'}]

roundup: ['Rise in economic inactivity among over 50s driven by retirements', 'Economic inactivity among those aged 50 years and over has increased since the start of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, following a historical downward trend over the previous 10 years.', 'The new Over 50s Lifestyle Study (OLS) asks those who left work during the pandemic about why they left and whether they intend to return.', 'Of those who had not returned to work, retirement was by far the most common reason for leaving paid work among people aged 50 to 70 years (47%), followed by the coronavirus pandemic (15%).', 'Compared with those who left work before the pandemic, those who left during the pandemic were more likely to:', ' - have left work sooner than they were expecting (63% compared with 54%)', ' - have left work not by choice (25% compared with 20%)', ' - consider returning to work (39% compared with 19%)']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the results from the Over 50s Lifestyle Study', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/over50slifestylestudyattitudesandreasonsforworkersover50leavingemploymentsincethestartofthepandemic'}]

roundup: ['Deaths involving COVID-19 increased in Wales', 'Of the 11,225 deaths registered in England and Wales in the week ending 4 March 2022, 670 mentioned "novel coronavirus (COVID-19)".', 'COVID-19 deaths in England and Wales accounted for 6.0% of all deaths; a decrease compared with the previous week (766 deaths, 6.9% of all deaths).', 'The number of deaths involving COVID-19 in Wales increased to 48 in the week ending 4 March 2022, compared with 43 in the previous week. In England, there was a decrease to 621 in the week ending 4 March 2022, compared with 722 in the previous week.', 'Of the 670 deaths involving COVID-19, 65.5% (439 deaths) had this recorded as the underlying cause of death in the week ending 4 March 2022, compared with 65.7% in the previous week.', 'The number of deaths registered in the UK in the week ending 4 March 2022 was 12,741, which was 51 deaths above the five-year average. Of the deaths registered 814 involved COVID-19, which was 65 fewer than in the previous week.', 'From the week ending 13 March 2020 to the week ending 4 March 2022, the number of excess deaths above the five-year average in England and Wales was 120,748; of these, 115,984 were recorded in England and 6,100 were recorded in Wales.', 'Our\u202fdata\u202fare based on deaths registered in England and Wales and include all deaths where “novel coronavirus (COVID-19)” was mentioned on the death certificate. Weekly figures are available by\u202flocal authority and health board.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest bulletin on deaths registered in England and Wales', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/birthsdeathsandmarriages/deaths/bulletins/deathsregisteredweeklyinenglandandwalesprovisional/latest'}]

roundup: ['Disabled people are more likely to feel life will never return to normal', 'Around one in six disabled people (16%) feel that their life will never return to normal after the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, according to Opinions and Lifestyle Survey (OPN) data from 16 to 27 February 2022.', 'Almost 1 in 10 non-disabled adults (11%) felt their life was already back to normal, compared with 6% among disabled people.', 'During the survey response period, most restrictions on daily life to curb the spread of coronavirus had been lifted in Great Britain.', 'Disabled people were more likely than non-disabled people to avoid crowded places, avoid close contact with those they do not live with, and spend more time at home because of coronavirus.', 'Young adults aged 16 to 24 years were the least likely to report avoiding crowded places because of coronavirus (33%) and were more than four times as likely as those aged 70 years and older to report not doing any of the listed behaviours (9% of adults aged 16 to 24 years compared with 2% of those aged 70 years and over).']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the full article on how the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic is affecting attitudes and behaviours', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/wellbeing/articles/coronaviruscovid19disabledpeoplearemorelikelytofeellifewillneverreturntonormal/2022-03-16'}]

roundup: ['Distrust and perceived risks top reasons for vaccine refusal', '“Side effects of the vaccine frightened me”', '“I cannot do anything that may risk my fertility”', '“If my body can fight it without a vaccine that’s good enough for me”', 'These are just some of the free-text responses collected as part of the Vaccine Opinions Study which provide insight into why some people remain unvaccinated.', 'Reasons for not vaccinating have been grouped into seven broad themes;', ' - feeling that the risks of a COVID-19 vaccine were too high or the benefits were too low', ' - distrusting or feeling discontent towards vaccine stakeholders', ' - lacking sufficient, trustworthy or favourable evidence on vaccine side effects, safety or effectiveness', ' - perceiving COVID-19 as low-risk to self', ' - feeling pressured or coerced', ' - worldview-related barriers', ' - practical barriers', 'The Vaccine Opinions Study identified changes in uptake and attitudes towards COVID-19 vaccines among adults in England who had reported having declined a vaccine when offered, being unlikely to have it or unsure about having it if offered, between 13 January and 8 August 2021. In this period, we saw a decline in this population from 10% to 3%.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the full article on Coronavirus and changing perceptions towards vaccination', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/coronavirusandchangingperceptionstowardsvaccinationengland7to16september2021'}]

roundup: ['COVID-19 mortality rates lowest for those with three vaccinations', 'The risk of death involving coronavirus (COVID-19) in England has been consistently lower for people who had a third vaccine dose or booster at least 21 days ago, compared with those who are unvaccinated.', 'This has been the case for all age groups across all months since boosters were introduced in September 2021.', 'People who had received a second vaccine dose over six months ago had a higher risk of death involving COVID-19 than those who had received a second dose less than six months ago, indicating possible waning protection from vaccination over time.', 'While these statistics are adjusted for age, they cannot be used to determine vaccine effectiveness. This is because vaccinated and unvaccinated people are likely to differ in characteristics other than age, such as underlying health. Some deaths are expected in vaccinated individuals as the number of people who are vaccinated is high and no vaccine is 100% effective.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the bulletin on deaths involving COVID-19 by vaccination status in England', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/birthsdeathsandmarriages/deaths/bulletins/deathsinvolvingcovid19byvaccinationstatusengland/latest'}]

roundup: ['Deaths involving COVID-19 increased in Wales', 'Of the 11,225 deaths registered in England and Wales in the week ending 4 March 2022, "novel coronavirus (COVID-19)" was mentioned on the death certificate of 670.', 'COVID-19 deaths in England and Wales accounted for 6.0% of all deaths; a decrease compared with the previous week (766 deaths, 6.9% of all deaths).', 'The number of deaths involving COVID-19 in Wales, increased to 48 in the week ending 4 March 2022, compared with 43 in the previous week. In England the number of deaths involving COVID-19 decreased to 621 in the week ending 4 March 2022, compared with 722 in the previous week.', 'Of the 670 deaths involving COVID-19, 65.5% (439 deaths) had this recorded as the underlying cause of death in the week ending 4 March 2022, compared with 65.7% in the previous week.', 'The number of deaths registered in the UK in the week ending 4 March 2022 was 12,741. This was 51 deaths above the five-year average of the deaths registered in the UK in the week ending 4 March 2022. Of the 12,741 deaths registered, 814 involved COVID-19, which was 65 fewer than in the previous week.', 'From the week ending 13 March 2020 to the week ending 4 March 2022, the number of excess deaths above the five-year average in England and Wales was 120,748. The total number recorded in England was 115,984, while the total number recorded in Wales was 6,100.', 'Our\u202fdata\u202fare based on deaths registered in England and Wales and include all deaths where “novel coronavirus (COVID-19)” was mentioned on the death certificate. Weekly figures are available by\u202flocal authority and health board.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest bulletin on deaths registered in England and Wales', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/birthsdeathsandmarriages/deaths/bulletins/deathsregisteredweeklyinenglandandwalesprovisional/latest'}]

roundup: ['Concern about COVID-19 at its lowest level', 'One-third (33%) of adults reported they were very or somewhat worried about the effect of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic on their lives. This figure is down from 41% in the previous period and is at its lowest level since the start of the pandemic.', 'Latest data from the Opinions and Lifestyle Survey also indicate a drop in social distancing. About 28% of adults now report they always or often maintain social distancing, down from 32% in the previous period. This figure is also at its lowest level since data were first collected for this measure in September 2020.', 'Six in ten (60%) working adults exclusively travelled to work; this was the highest level since the measure was first recorded in May 2020 when only 29% of working adult were exclusively travelling to work.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest bulletin on the social impacts of COVID-19', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/coronavirusandthesocialimpactsongreatbritain18march2022'}]

roundup: ['Infections rise for a further week across UK', 'The percentage of people estimated to test positive for coronavirus (COVID-19) rose in England, Wales and Scotland in the week ending 12 March 2022.', 'The percentage in Northern Ireland was uncertain in the most recent week, but increased in the two weeks up to 12 March 2022.', 'The estimated number of people living in private households (not in hospitals, care homes or other communal establishments) who had COVID-19 in the most recent week was:', ' - 2,653,200 people (1 in 20) in England', ' - 125,400 people (1 in 25) in Wales', ' - 130,600 people (1 in 14) in Northern Ireland', ' - 376,300 people (1 in 14) in Scotland', 'In the week ending 12 March 2022, the percentage of infections compatible with the Omicron BA.2 variant increased in England, Wales and Scotland and the trend was uncertain in Northern Ireland. The percentage of infections compatible with the Omicron BA.1 variant decreased in England, Northern Ireland and Scotland and the trend was uncertain in Wales.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest Coronavirus (COVID-19) Infection Survey bulletin', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/bulletins/coronaviruscovid19infectionsurveypilot/latest'}]

roundup: ['Nearly two-thirds of students have had the booster vaccination', 'The majority (92%) of students have said they have been vaccinated against coronavirus (COVID-19) at least once.', 'Almost two-thirds (65%) have received the booster dose.', 'Of those who have not received a booster dose, 7 in 10 (70%) said they were very or fairly likely to have one or had an appointment confirmed.', 'This is according to responses to the Student COVID-19 Insights Survey (SCIS) in England between 25 February and 7 March 2022.', 'Over half (62%) of respondents said they would stay at home for at least 5 days if they developed symptoms of COVID-19; this is similar to late November 2021 when the legal isolation period was 10 days (60%).', 'More than one-third (36%) of students reported that their mental health and well-being had worsened since the start of the Autumn 2021 term, up from 28% in late November 2021.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the bulletin on coronavirus and higher education students in England', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/healthandwellbeing/bulletins/coronavirusandhighereducationstudents/latest'}]

roundup: ['Births rose in 2021 for the first time in six years', 'Provisional data for 2021 shows the fertility rate in England and Wales increased year-on-year for the first time since 2012.', 'There were 625,008 live births, an increase of 1.5% from 2020. This remains well below the 2019 number and continues a long-term trend of falling numbers of live births.', 'Most of the increase in live births occurred during the second half of 2021. These relate mostly to births conceived during coronavirus (COVID-19) restrictions from November 2020 to March 2021.', 'The total fertility rate (TFR) rose to 1.61 children per woman in 2021, up from 1.58 in 2020.', 'The increase in fertility has been driven by women at older ages.', 'In 2021, the age-specific fertility rates (ASFR) of women aged under 20 years and those aged 20 to 24 years decreased, whereas in all other age groups fertility rates increased.', 'The largest increase in ASFR was those aged 35 to 39 years, which increased by 5.2%, from 59.4 live births per 1,000 women in 2020 to 62.5 in 2021.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest insights on COVID-19 and its impact on society', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/articles/coronaviruscovid19latestinsights/lifestyle#impact-on-everyday-life'}, {'text': 'Read the full bulletin on Provisional births in England and Wales: 2021', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/provisionalbirthsinenglandandwales2021'}]

roundup: ['Deaths involving COVID-19 continue to fall', 'The number of deaths in the UK involving coronavirus (COVID-19) fell to 814 in the week ending 11 March 2022. This was 65 fewer than the previous week, accounting for around 1 in every 15 deaths (6.4%).', 'There were 12,772 total deaths registered in the UK in the week ending 11 March 2022, which was 1.5% below the five-year average.', 'Of the 671 deaths registered in England and Wales where “novel coronavirus (COVID-19)” was mentioned on the death certificate, 62.1% (417 deaths) had this recorded as the underlying cause of death. This is down from 65.5% in the previous week.', 'Between 13 March 2020 and 25 February 2022, there were 120,571 excess deaths above the five-year average in England and Wales; of these, 115,797 were recorded in England and 6,104 were\u202frecorded in Wales.', 'Between March 2020 and December 2021, there were 133,623 excess deaths due to all causes registered in England and Wales. 81,885 of these were males and 51,737 were females. The highest numbers of excess deaths were recorded in April 2020 and January 2021.', 'For deaths where the underlying cause of death was not COVID-19, excess deaths were 7,401 below the five-year average (2015 to 2019); deaths were 4,150 above the five-year average for males and 11,552 below the five-year average for females.', 'For deaths due to causes other than COVID-19, three of the nine English regions saw an increase on the five-year average: West Midlands (1,134 excess deaths, a 1.1% increase), East Midlands (409 excess deaths, a 0.5% increase), and the South West (165 excess deaths, a 0.2% increase).', 'Our\u202fdata\u202fare based on deaths registered in England and Wales and include all deaths where “novel coronavirus (COVID-19)” was mentioned on the death certificate. Weekly figures are available by\u202flocal authority and health board.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest bulletin on deaths registered in England and Wales', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/birthsdeathsandmarriages/deaths/bulletins/deathsregisteredweeklyinenglandandwalesprovisional/latest'}, {'text': 'Read the full bulletin on excess deaths in England and Wales: March 2020 to December 2021', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/excessdeathsinenglandandwalesmarch2020todecember2021'}]

roundup: ['COVID-19 was the third-leading cause of death in England in February 2022', 'Coronavirus (COVID-19) was the third-leading cause of death in England in February 2022, accounting for 5.6% of deaths. In Wales, COVID-19 was the sixth-leading cause of death, accounting for 4.4% of all deaths.', 'Considering the population size and age structure, the age-standardised mortality rate (ASMR) for deaths due to COVID-19 decreased significantly between January and February 2022 in both England (55.3 deaths per 100,000 people, down from 79.3) and Wales (45.7 deaths per 100,000 people, down from 81.0).', 'The North East had the highest ASMR for deaths due to COVID-19 among English regions in February, with 75.4 deaths per 100,000 people.', 'The proportion of deaths due to COVID-19 (of all deaths involving COVID-19), decreased between January and February 2022, from 73.7% to 66.0% in England and from 76.2% to 61.7% in Wales.', 'In total, there were 43,081 deaths from all causes registered in England in February 2022, 3,338 (7.2%) fewer than the five-year average (2016 to 2019, and 2021).', 'There were 2,730 deaths registered in Wales in February, 267 (8.9%) fewer than the February average.', 'The leading cause of death in February 2022 was dementia and Alzheimers’ disease in England, followed by ischaemic heart disease and COVID-19. In Wales, the leading cause of death was ischaemic heart disease, followed by dementia and Alzheimers’ disease and cerebrovascular diseases (which include strokes and aneurisms).']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest monthly mortality analysis for England and Wales', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/monthlymortalityanalysisenglandandwalesjanuary2022'}]

roundup: ['White British school pupils most likely to report a positive test', 'Almost one-quarter (24.9%) of White British secondary school pupils reported a positive coronavirus (COVID-19) test in the Autumn 2021 term. This is the highest percentage of any ethnicity.', 'In the Autumn 2020 term, the highest percentage of positive tests was among Indian secondary school pupils, with 11.3%.', 'Among primary school pupils, White British pupils also had the largest percentage of their population reporting a positive test in the Autumn 2021 term (16.6%). In the Autumn 2020 term, Pakistani pupils were the most likely to report a positive test (2.5%).', 'Pupils aged 12 to 15 years vaccinated with one dose were 38% less likely to report a positive test than an unvaccinated pupil between 20 September and 3 November 2021. Between 4 November and 17 December 2021, pupils vaccinated with one dose were 23% less likely to report a positive test compared with unvaccinated pupils. These comparisons are calculated after controlling for differences in the characteristics between vaccinated and unvaccinated pupils and looks at pupils who received their vaccine dose at least 14 days previously.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the full bulletin on coronavirus cases in school pupils', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/coronaviruscovid19casesinschoolpupilsenglandupto31december2021'}]

roundup: ['Antibodies remain high across the UK', 'The proportion of the population estimated to have antibodies against coronavirus (COVID-19) remains high in each UK nation and across all age groups. The proportion of adults estimated to have COVID-19 antibodies above the 179 nanograms per millilitre (ng/ml) threshold, in the week beginning 28 February 2022 were:']

['Infections continue to increase in England, Wales and Scotland', 'The percentage of people testing positive for coronavirus (COVID-19) continued to increase in England in the week ending 19 March 2022, with rises seen across all regions and age groups.', 'The percentage testing positive also increased in Wales and Scotland in the most recent week, but it decreased in Northern Ireland.', 'The data for Scotland refer to the week ending 20 March 2022.', 'The estimated number of people living in private households (not in hospitals, care homes and/or other communal establishments) that had COVID-19 in the most recent week was:', ' - 3,485,700 people (1 in 16) in England', ' - 192,900 people (1 in 16) in Wales', ' - 108,700 people (1 in 17) in Northern Ireland', ' - 473,800 people (1 in 11) in Scotland']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest results from the Coronavirus (COVID-19) Infection Survey', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/bulletins/coronaviruscovid19infectionsurveypilot/latest'}]

roundup: ['Most deprived areas of England and Wales saw higher avoidable mortality rates in 2020', 'Avoidable mortality rates on account of coronavirus (COVID-19) were higher in the most deprived areas of England and Wales, compared with the least deprived areas.', 'Avoidable deaths are those considered preventable or treatable for those aged under 75 years, and COVID-19 has been assigned as a preventable cause of death.', 'The age-standardised mortality rate (ASMR) for COVID-19 in the most deprived areas of England was 95.1 deaths per 100,000 males, and 53.3 deaths per 100,000 females. This was more than four times higher for men, and more than five times higher for women than in the least deprived areas.', 'In the least deprived areas, the ASMR was 21.9 deaths per 100,000 males, and 9.4 deaths per 100,000 females.', 'Overall, avoidable mortality rates increased in England in 2020, compared with 2019, reversing a long-term decline in avoidable mortality rates.', 'In Wales, the ASMR in the most deprived areas was 91.3 deaths per 100,000 males, and 53.6 deaths per 100,000 females. In the least deprived areas, the ASMR was 32.7 deaths per 100,000 males, and 14.9 deaths per 100,000 females.', 'In Wales, the ASMR for avoidable deaths increased in 2020 compared with 2019, but the increase was only statistically significant among females living in the most deprived areas.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the full bulletin on Socioeconomic inequalities in avoidable mortality, England and Wales: 2020', 'link': None}]

roundup: ['Child victims of modern slavery and the coronavirus', 'The number of child victims of modern slavery identified by the police and through the National Referral Mechanism (NRM) continues to increase.', 'However, in the latest year we have seen falls in potential victims indicated by other data sources. This could be due to the impact of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic and lockdown restrictions and makes measuring the underlying number of child victims even more challenging.', 'Modern slavery covers all forms of slavery, human trafficking and exploitation. It is a hidden crime with victims often unable to come forward due to fear or shame, or because they are unable to leave their situation.', 'This is our first attempt to bring together data sources on child victims of modern slavery.', 'In the year ending December 2021, the number of referrals of children to the NRM increased by 9% compared with the previous year (from 5,028 to 5,468), continuing an upward trend over time.', 'Changes in police recording practices and the coronavirus pandemic have likely affected the number of child victims identified in recent years. Other data sources show:', ' - an increase of 27% (to 3,239) in the number of modern slavery offences involving a child victim recorded by the police in England and Wales in the year ending March 2021 compared with the previous year', ' - 16,830 episodes of need for child sexual exploitation and 2,710 for trafficking identified by the Department for Education’s children in need census in the year ending March 2021, both representing a 10% decrease from the previous year; likely the result of a fall in referrals from schools during the pandemic', ' - a 43% decrease in the number of potential child victims reported to the Modern Slavery and Exploitation Helpline in the year ending December 2021 compared with the previous year', 'Information about finding help is available in our bulletin.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the full bulletin on child victims of modern slavery in the UK', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/crimeandjustice/bulletins/childvictimsofmodernslaveryintheuk/latest'}]

This is up from 62.1% in the previous week.', 'Between 13 March 2020 and 18 March 2022, there were 126,529 excess deaths above the five-year average in England and Wales; of these, 121,395 were recorded in England and 6,445 were\u202frecorded in Wales.', 'Our\u202fdata\u202fare based on deaths registered in England and Wales and include all deaths where “novel coronavirus (COVID-19)” was mentioned on the death certificate. Weekly figures are available by\u202flocal authority and health board.']

roundup: ['Two-thirds self-isolating fully after legal requirement lifted', 'Just over two-thirds (64%) of people who tested positive for coronavirus (COVID-19) fully complied with self-isolation advice for their full isolation period after the legal requirement to do so was lifted.', 'This was statistically significantly lower than the levels of full compliance reported in February 2022 (80%), when self-isolation was a legal requirement.', 'Of those who were non-compliant, 94% reported leaving the house for a reason other than to get or return a COVID-19 test or for an emergency medical treatment or hospital attendance.', 'This was statistically significantly higher than in the previous wave (85%) when self-isolation was a legal requirement.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest insights on COVID-19 and lifestyle', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/articles/coronaviruscovid19latestinsights/lifestyle'}, {'text': 'Read the full release on Coronavirus and self-isolation after testing positive in England', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/coronavirusandselfisolationaftertestingpositiveinengland28februaryto8march2022'}]

roundup: ['Children and those aged around 30 years more likely to test positive for coronavirus', 'Children and those aged around 30 years were more likely to test positive for the coronavirus (COVID-19) than people of other ages.', 'Data on the characteristics of people testing positive for COVID-19 in the fortnight up to 12 March also show that people from ethnic minority groups were less likely to test positive than those reporting White ethnicity.', 'It also showed:', ' - people living in multigenerational households were less likely to test positive than people not living in multigenerational households', ' - people who were not working were less likely to test positive than those who were employed and working', ' - females were less likely to test positive than males', ' - people who were affected “a lot” by a disability were less likely to test positive than those who were not impacted by a disability', ' - people who work in a care or nursing homes were more likely to test positive than those who did not', ' - those living in larger households in Northern Ireland and Scotland were more likely to test positive, but this was not the case in many other parts of the UK.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the full COVID-19 Infection Survey bulletin on the characteristics of people testing positive for COVID-19', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/bulletins/coronaviruscovid19infectionsurveycharacteristicsofpeopletestingpositiveforcovid19uk/latest'}]

roundup: ['Hybrid model of working used by 21% of UK workforce', 'More than one-fifth of the UK workforce (21%) was estimated to be using a hybrid model of working in early March 2022. This was 6 percentage points higher than the start of start of 2022.', 'In the two weeks ending 19 March 2022, the percentage of people self-isolating because of coronavirus (COVID-19) has significantly increased in all work sectors except for the “Food production, agriculture, farming” work sector, according to data from the Coronavirus (COVID-19) Infection Survey.', 'The sectors with the highest percentage of the workforce in self-isolation on 19 March 2022 were “arts, entertainment or recreation” and “social care”, at 3.8% and 3.6%, respectively.', 'Potential redundancies and the number of employers proposing redundancies fell by 7% and 3% respectively in the last week. The labour market continues to remain tight with total online job adverts at 135% of their February 2020 average level on 25 March 2022.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest bulletin on economic and social change in the UK', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/economicoutputandproductivity/output/bulletins/economicactivityandsocialchangeintheukrealtimeindicators/latest'}]

roundup: ['Two-thirds self-isolating fully after legal requirement lifted', 'Around two-thirds (64%) of people who tested positive for coronavirus (COVID-19) fully complied with self-isolation advice for their full isolation period after the legal requirement to do so was lifted.', 'This was statistically significantly lower than the levels of full compliance reported in February 2022 (80%), when self-isolation was a legal requirement.', 'Of those who were non-compliant, 94% reported leaving the house for a reason other than to get or return a COVID-19 test or for an emergency medical treatment or hospital attendance.', 'This was statistically significantly higher than in the previous wave (85%) when self-isolation was a legal requirement.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest insights on COVID-19 and lifestyle', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/articles/coronaviruscovid19latestinsights/lifestyle'}, {'text': 'Read the full release on Coronavirus and self-isolation after testing positive in England', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/coronavirusandselfisolationaftertestingpositiveinengland28februaryto8march2022'}]

roundup: ['COVID-19 infections highest in England and Wales since survey began', 'The percentage of people testing positive for coronavirus (COVID-19) continues to rise in England and Wales and is estimated to be at the highest level since the Coronavirus Infection Survey began.', 'In the week ending 26 March 2022, an estimated 4,122,700 people in England (7.56%) and 212,000 people in Wales (6.97%) are estimated to have had COVID-19.', 'The previous highest levels in these countries were 6.85% in England in the week to 6 January 2022, and 6.35% in Wales in the week to 19 March 2022.', 'Trends in Scotland and Northern Ireland in the latest week are less certain.', 'The estimated percentage of the community population (those not in hospitals, care homes or other institutional settings) that had COVID-19 was:', ' - 7.56% in England (1 in 13 people)', ' - 6.97% in Wales (1 in 14 people)', ' - 6.70% in Northern Ireland (1 in 15 people)', ' - 8.57% in Scotland (1 in 12 people)', 'Our latest complete sequenced data are for the week ending 20 March 2022 and show that the Omicron BA.2 variant remains the most common variant in all UK nations.', 'In this week, 89.8% of all sequenced COVID-19 infections from the survey were compatible with the Omicron BA.2 variant, and 10.2% were compatible with the Omicron BA.1 variant or its sub-variants.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest results from the Coronavirus (COVID-19) Infection Survey', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/bulletins/coronaviruscovid19infectionsurveypilot/latest'}]

roundup: ['Concern about the coronavirus pandemic’s impact remained low', 'About one-third of adults (35%) reported they were very or somewhat worried about the effect the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic was having on their lives. This follows a decline from 66% between 15 December 2021 and 3 January 2022.', 'Around seven in ten adults (68%) reported wearing a face covering when outside the home. This is the lowest proportion since the removal of Plan B measures in England at the end of January 2022 (95% over the period 19 to 30 January 2022).', 'The share of people reporting always or often maintaining social distancing remained relatively stable (29% in the latest week). The previous week’s figure of 28% was the lowest since this measure was first recorded in September 2020 (76% over the period 16 to 20 September 2020).', 'Four in ten adults (40%) reported taking a rapid lateral flow test in the past seven days, following a decline from 61% over the period 6 to 16 January 2022.', 'Around six in ten (57%) working adults exclusively travelled to work. Although slightly lower than the previous period (60%), the figure remains considerably higher than when this measure was first recorded (29% over the period 14 to 17 May 2020).']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest bulletin on coronavirus and the social impacts on Great Britain', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/healthandwellbeing/bulletins/coronavirusandthesocialimpactsongreatbritain/latest'}]

roundup: ['Vaccination coverage highest among health professionals', 'As of 28 February 2022, 74.5% of adults aged 18 to 64 years who were employed had received three coronavirus (COVID-19) vaccinations and 7.2% were unvaccinated.', 'The occupation groups with the highest proportion of people who had received three vaccinations were health professionals (84.7%) and teaching and other educational professionals (83.6%).', 'However, there was large variation between occupations. Within the health professionals group, 93.3% of specialist medical practitioners had received three vaccinations, compared with 71.9% of therapy professionals not elsewhere classified.', 'Elementary trades and related occupations (57.6%) and skilled construction and building trades (61.8%) had the lowest proportions of people with three vaccinations. These groups also had the highest proportions of people who had not received a vaccine, at 15.1% and 12.7% respectively.', 'The differences in vaccination status between occupation groups and industry sections did not appear to be driven by differences in geography, socio-demographic characteristics or underlying health conditions, as the rankings largely remained unchanged after adjusting for these factors.', 'Vaccination rates are produced using the Office for National Statistics Public Health Data Asset. Data may differ from weekly administrative vaccination data published by NHS England.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the full article on coronavirus vaccination rates by occupation and industry in England', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/coronavirusandvaccinationratesinpeopleaged18to64yearsbyoccupationandindustryengland28february2022'}]

roundup: ['COVID-19 antibody prevalence increases in school pupils', 'Coronavirus (COVID-19) antibodies were detected in 96.6% of secondary and 62.4% of primary school pupils in England during Round 2 of coronavirus Schools Infection Survey (SIS) in the academic year ending 2022.', 'The SIS found that antibody prevalence was significantly higher in Round 2 (January to February) than Round 1 (November to December) for both primary and secondary school pupils. The SARS-CoV-2 antibody prevalence continues to steadily increase by age for all pupils.', 'Antibody testing in Round 2 took place while c oronavirus cases in England were increasing, especially among school-aged children, because of the Omicron variant (declared a variant of concern on 27 November 2021). It is likely that antibody prevalence is higher in Round 2 than Round 1 because of both an increase in infections in the community and the continuing vaccination programme for secondary school-aged pupils.', 'Of secondary school pupils tested in Round 2, 46.6% had received at least one vaccination dose at least 14 days before their antibody test. No primary school pupils tested in Round 2 were vaccinated.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest COVID-19 Schools Infection Survey bulletin', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/covid19schoolsinfectionsurveyenglandpupilantibodydatajanuarytofebruary2022'}]

roundup: ['Coronavirus (COVID-19) antibodies remained high', 'In the week beginning 14 March 2022, the percentage of adults that had coronavirus (COVID-19) antibodies remained high in all UK nations.', 'In England and Wales, 98.8% of the adult population were estimated to have COVID-19 antibodies above a threshold of 179 nanograms per millilitre. In Northern Ireland, 99.0% of adults had antibodies, and in Scotland, 98.9%.', 'Across the UK, the percentage of children estimated to have antibodies ranged from 95.9% to 97.2% for those aged 12 to 15 years, and from 76.6% to 85.3% for those aged 8 to 11 years.', 'Children aged under 12 years are not currently eligible for vaccination, so antibodies in this age group are most likely a result of previous infection.', 'These statistics refer to antibody tests for people living in private households.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest Coronavirus (COVID-19) Infection Survey bulletin on UK antibody data', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/bulletins/coronaviruscovid19infectionsurveyantibodyandvaccinationdatafortheuk/latest'}]

roundup: ['COVID-19 caused a larger impact on spending than the 2008 recession', 'The coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic caused a larger impact on household spending in the UK than the 2008 financial crisis.', 'Unprecedented public health measures during the pandemic caused an uneven fall in spending on goods and services. Reduced spending in restaurants, hotels and transport services were the main drivers for the overall fall in spending, along with changes in the ways goods and services were consumed following the start of the recovery from the pandemic.', 'New insights from card spending transaction data show that the emergence of the Omicron coronavirus variant in late 2021 led to relatively lower levels of spending in pubs, restaurants and fast-food venues along with entertainment, and travel and hotels. Meanwhile there was a relative increase in spending on food and drink.', 'During the first two quarters of the pandemic, household spending fell 22.2% because of the introduction of lockdown and other public health restrictions, which particularly impacted “social spending”, such as restaurants and cafes, recreation and culture. Household spending recovered 19.6% in the following quarter and had almost returned to pre-coronavirus levels after two years following the pandemic. Following the financial crisis, household spending took over five years to recover.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest insights on COVID-19 and lifestyle', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/articles/coronaviruscovid19latestinsights/lifestyle'}, {'text': 'Read the bulletin on Coronavirus (COVID-19) and its effects on household consumption, UK: January 2020 to December 2021', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/coronaviruscovid19anditseffectsonhouseholdconsumptionukjanuary2020tojanuary2022'}]

roundup: ['UK passengers find overseas COVID restrictions easy to follow', 'Most UK residents (85%) returning from abroad said that they found it “easy” or “very easy” to follow the coronavirus (COVID-19) restrictions in the country they had visited. The main reason cited by those who struggled with restrictions was that the information was “difficult to follow, or overly restrictive”.', 'Data collected in February 2022 also suggest that most travellers arriving in the UK think that having a coronavirus test prior to arrival is important. About 69% of UK residents and 78% of overseas residents said it was either “very important” or “quite important” for safety.', 'Three-quarters of travelers (75% of UK and 78% of overseas residents) said that the wearing of face coverings made them feel safe during their journey into the UK. Three-quarters of travelers also said that the availability of hand sanitizer during their journey also made them feel safe (74% of UK and 75% of overseas residents).', 'In February 2022, most UK residents (91%) and overseas residents (88%) arriving in the UK said they had received at least two COVID-19 vaccinations. Two in three UK residents and half of overseas residents arriving in the UK had received more than two COVID-19 vaccinations.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest insights on COVID-19 and lifestyle', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/articles/coronaviruscovid19latestinsights/lifestyle'}, {'text': 'Read the full release on Attitudes towards COVID-19 among passengers travelling into and out of the UK', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/attitudestowardscovid19amongpassengerstravellingintoandoutoftheukseptember2021tofebruary2022'}]

roundup: ['Deaths in private homes above five-year average', 'Of the 10,745 deaths registered in England and Wales in the week ending 25 March 2022, 780 (7.3%) mentioned "novel coronavirus (COVID-19)".', 'The majority (62.6%), 488 of those 780 deaths registered in the week ending 25 March 2022 (Week 12) had COVID-19 as the underlying cause of death compared with 65.3% in the previous week (Week 11).', 'The number of deaths in England and Wales in Week 12 was above the five-year average in private homes (23.6%) but below the five-year average in hospitals (4.8% below, 234 fewer deaths). In Week 12, the number of deaths was 3.6% below average in care homes (81 fewer deaths) and 2.0% below the average for other settings (16 fewer deaths).', 'The number of deaths registered in the UK in the week ending 25 March 2022 (Week 12), was 12,344; 3.8% above the five-year average (448 more deaths). Of these deaths, 1,005 involved coronavirus (COVID-19), which was 176 more than in Week 11.', 'The data refer to the date on which a death is registered, not the date of d eath. Deaths in England and Wales are normally registered within five days, but there can be a considerably longer delay in some circumstances, particularly when the death is referred to a coroner.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the bulletin Deaths registered in England and Wales, provisional: week ending 25 March 2022', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/deathsregisteredweeklyinenglandandwalesprovisionalweekending25march2022'}]

roundup: ['1 in 37 people in the UK have long COVID', 'An estimated 1.7 million people living in private households in the UK were experiencing self-reported long COVID as of 5 March 2022.', 'This is around 2.7% of the population, or 1 in every 37 people, with symptoms persisting for more than four weeks after the first suspected coronavirus (COVID-19) infection that were not explained by something else.', 'Of those, 1.2 million people (69%) first had (or suspected they had) COVID-19 at least 12 weeks previously, 784,000 (45%) at least one year previously and 74,000 (4%) at least two years previously.', "Fatigue continued to be the most common symptom reported as part of individuals' experience of long COVID (51% of those with self-reported long COVID), followed by shortness of breath (34%), loss of smell (28%), and muscle ache (24%)."]
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the full release on Prevalence of ongoing symptoms following coronavirus (COVID-19) infection in the UK', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/prevalenceofongoingsymptomsfollowingcoronaviruscovid19infectionintheuk7april2022'}]

roundup: ['COVID-19 death rates higher for many ethnic minorities during Omicron', 'Rates of death involving coronavirus (COVID-19) remained highest among many ethnic minority groups while the Omicron variant has been dominant.', 'Between 10 January and 16 February 2022, rates of deaths involving COVID-19 were highest for the Bangladeshi and Pakistani ethnic groups. This is similar to patterns observed before Omicron became the main variant.', 'Since Omicron became the main variant, men in the Bangladeshi ethnic group had the highest rate of death involving COVID-19, 2.7 times higher than men in the White British ethnic group, followed by Pakistani men (2.2 times) and Black Caribbean men (1.6 times).', 'Women in the Pakistani ethnic group had the highest rate of death involving COVID-19, 2.5 times higher than women in the White British ethnic group, followed by Bangladeshi women (1.9 times) and women in the Mixed ethnic group (1.4 times).', 'Since the pandemic began, patterns in death rates from all causes have been reversed among some ethnic groups.', 'For example, all-cause mortality rates during the pandemic (24 January 2020 to 16 February 2022), were higher for Bangladeshi men and women, Black Caribbean men and Pakistani men compared to the White British group.', 'This differs from pre-pandemic all-cause mortality rates which were highest for the White British and Mixed ethnic groups.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the full bulletin on ethnic contrasts in deaths involving COVID-19', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/updatingethniccontrastsindeathsinvolvingthecoronaviruscovid19englandsince10january2022'}, {'text': 'Explore the latest insights on COVID-19 and death', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/articles/coronaviruscovid19latestinsights/deaths'}]

roundup: ['Well-being levels out across all measures', 'While the covid-19 pandemic has impacted people’s reporting of their personal well-being, during the periods Quarter 2 (Apr to Jun) 2021 and Quarter 3 (July to Sept) 2021 there has been little change to well-being.', 'During periods of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, both males and females saw an increase in anxiety and a reduction in life satisfaction, feeling that the things done in life are worthwhile, and happiness.', 'Our previous pre-pandemic analysis has shown females have the same or higher life satisfaction and happiness than males.', 'However, females reported lower levels of life satisfaction than males in Quarter 4 (Oct to Dec) 2020 and Quarter 1 (Jan to Mar) 2021, and lower happiness than males in Quarter 2 2020 (Apr to Jun), Quarter 4 2020, and Quarter 1 2021.', 'The declines in life satisfaction and happiness largely recovered by Quarter 2 2021 for both sexes. There was no significant change in these indicators for either sex during Quarter 3 2021, where there was also no longer a significant difference between the sexes.', 'For males, happiness scores in Quarter 2 and Quarter 3 2021 and life satisfaction scores in Quarter 3 2021 returned to levels seen in corresponding 2019 periods.', 'For females, Quarter 2 and Quarter 3 (Jul to Sept) 2021, happiness scores returned to levels seen in corresponding 2019 periods, but life satisfaction remained below levels seen in corresponding 2019 periods.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read Personal well-being in the UK, quarterly: April 2011 to September 2021', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/personalwellbeingintheukquarterlyapril2011toseptember2021'}, {'text': 'Explore the latest insights on COVID-19 and well-being', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/articles/coronaviruscovid19latestinsights/wellbeing'}]

roundup: ['UK spending and OpenTable seated diners increased by 6 percentage points', 'UK spending on credit and debit cards and OpenTable UK seated diners both increased by 6 percentage points in the latest week.', 'Consumer activity across the UK showed a mixed picture in the most recent week, with visits to retail stores and recreation areas at 15% below pre-coronavirus (COVID-19) levels; 1% lower than the previous week, according to Google Mobility data. Additionally, Springboard’s retail footfall decreased by 8% from the previous week.', 'Visits to retail and recreation locations have not yet returned to pre-coronavirus levels and remain below pre-Omicron variant levels. There has been a slow upward trend in visits to workspaces since the low of April 2020, but these are still 21% below pre-coronavirus levels. Visits to transit stations have been the slowest to recover and are still 28% below pre-coronavirus levels.', 'Visits to each location type in the week to 1 April 2022 compared with the previous week:', ' - Parks decreased by 12%', ' - No change in transit stations', ' - Grocery and pharmacy increased by 1%', ' - Retail and recreation decreased by 1%', ' - Workplaces increased by 1%']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the full bulletin on Economic activity and social change in the UK, real-time indicators', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/economicactivityandsocialchangeintheukrealtimeindicators7april2022'}, {'text': 'Read the UK economy latest roundup', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/economicoutputandproductivity/output/articles/ukeconomylatest/2021-01-25'}]

roundup: ['Infection rates remain high across the UK', 'The percentage of people testing positive for coronavirus (COVID-19) remained high in England and continued to increase in Wales in the week ending 2 April 2022.', 'Meanwhile, the percentage testing positive decreased in Scotland and the trend was uncertain in Northern Ireland in the most recent week.', 'Infection levels in England and Wales were the highest recorded since the study began.', 'The data for Scotland refer to the week ending 3 April 2022.', 'The estimated number of people living in private households (not in hospitals, care homes and/or other communal establishments) that had COVID-19 in the most recent week was:', ' - 4,141,600 people (1 in 13) in England', ' - 230,800 people (1 in 13) in Wales', ' - 113,900 people (1 in 16) in Northern Ireland', ' - 396,800 people (1 in 13) in Scotland']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest results from the Coronavirus (COVID-19) Infection Survey', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/healthandsocialcare/conditionsanddiseases/bulletins/coronaviruscovid19infectionsurveypilot/latest'}]

roundup: ['Vaccinated remain less likely to test positive for COVID-19', 'Most people in the UK who reported having been vaccinated against the coronavirus (COVID-19) continued to be less likely to test positive for the virus than those who reported not being vaccinated in the fortnight ending 26 March 2022.', 'Those who had already been infected with COVID-19 continued to be less likely to test positive than those who had not experienced a prior infection in the fortnight ending 26 March 2022.', 'Other characteristics of people testing positive for COVID-19 in the UK in the fortnight up to 26 March 2022 were that people who reported that they had travelled abroad in the last 28 days continued to be more likely to test positive for COVID-19 than those who had not.', 'People who reported working outside the home 2, 3, or 4 days per week were more likely to test positive than those who reported not working outside the home, in the fortnight up to 26 March 2022.', 'Meanwhile the percentage of people testing positive who reported loss of taste or smell remained at low levels in March 2022, after decreasing sharply between December 2021 and January 2022 (during the time when the Omicron variants became most common).']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the latest bulletin Coronavirus Infection Survey, UK: characteristics of people testing positive for COVID-19', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/coronaviruscovid19infectionsurveyukcharacteristicsofpeopletestingpositiveforcovid1913april2022'}]

roundup: ['Deaths in care homes below five-year average', 'Of the 9,840 deaths registered in England and Wales in the week ending 1 April 2022 (Week 13), 853 (8.7%) mentioned "novel coronavirus (COVID-19)".', 'Of such deaths, 62.0% (529 out of 853) had COVID-19 as the underlying cause of death compared with 62.6% in the previous week (Week 12).', 'In Week 13, the number of excess deaths in care homes in England and Wales was 7.0% below average and 3.0% below the five-year average in hospitals. The number of excess deaths in private homes was 21.7% above the five-year average but 10.1% below the average for other settings.', 'The number of deaths registered in the UK in Week 13 was 11,439, which is 3.6% above the five-year average (398 more deaths). Of these deaths, 1,061 involved coronavirus, which was 55 more than in Week 12.', 'The data refer to the date on which a death is registered, not the date of death. Deaths in England and Wales are normally registered within five days, but there can be a considerably longer delay in some circumstances, particularly when the death is referred to a coroner.']
bulletin_url: [{'text': 'Read the bulletin Deaths registered in England and Wales, provisional: week ending 1 April 2022', 'link': 'https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/deathsregisteredweeklyinenglandandwalesprovisionalweekending1april2022'}]

There was no significant change in these indicators for either sex during Quarter 3 2021, where there was also no longer a significant difference between the sexes.', 'For males, happiness scores in Quarter 2 and Quarter 3 2021 and life satisfaction scores in Quarter 3 2021 returned to levels seen in corresponding 2019 periods.', 'For females, Quarter 2 and Quarter 3 (Jul to Sept) 2021, happiness scores returned to levels seen in corresponding 2019 periods, but life satisfaction remained below levels seen in corresponding 2019 periods.']
